00017 =head1 NAME
00018 
00019 PGchoicemacros.pl - Macros for multiple choice, matching, and true/false questions.
00020 
00021 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00022 
00023 Matching example:
00024 
00025  loadMacros("PGchoicemacros.pl");
00026  
00027  # create a new match list
00028  $ml = new_match_list();
00029  
00030  # enter three questions and their answers
00031  $ml->qa(
00032     "What color is a rose?",
00033     "Red",
00034     "What color is the sky?",
00035     "Blue",
00036     "What color is the sea?",
00037     "Green",
00038  );
00039  
00040  # choose two of these questions, ordered at random,
00041  # which will be printed in the problem.
00042  $ml->choose(2);
00043  
00044  # print the question and answer choices
00045  BEGIN_TEXT
00046  Match the answers below with these questions: $BR
00047  \{ $ml->print_q \} $BR
00048  Answers:
00049  \{ $ml->print_a \}
00050  END_TEXT
00051  
00052  # register the correct answer
00053  ANS($ml->ra_correct_ans);
00054 
00055 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00056 
00057 There are two types of choice macros. The older versions are simple subroutines.
00058 The newer versions involve the List class and its sub-classes and the use of
00059 objects based on these classes. The list sub-classes are:
00060 
00061 =over
00062 
00063 =item *
00064 
00065 B<Match>, which aids in setting up matching question and answer lists,
00066 
00067 =item *
00068 
00069 B<Select>, which aids in selecting and presenting a subset of questions with short
00070 answers (e.g. true/false questions) from a larger question set, and
00071 
00072 =item *
00073 
00074 B<Multiple>, which aids in setting up a standard one-question-many-answers multiple
00075 choice question.
00076 
00077 =back
00078 
00079 =cut
00080 
00081 # ^uses be_strict
00082 BEGIN{
00083     be_strict;
00084 }
00085 
00086 package main;
00087 
00088 
00089 BEGIN {
00090     be_strict();
00091 }

00094 
00095 sub _PGchoicemacros_init{
00096 }

00099 
00100 =cut

00102 ################################################################################
00103 
00104 =head2 Match lists
00105 
00106 =over
00107 
00108 =item new_match_list
00109 
00110  $ml = new_match_list();
00111 
00112 new_match_list() creates a new Match object and initializes it with sensible
00113 defaults. It is equivalent to:
00114 
00115  $ml = new Match(random(1,2000,1), ~~&std_print_q, ~~&std_print_a);
00116 
00117 The first argument is the seed for the match list (choosen at random between 1
00118 and 2000 in the example above). The next two arguments are references to the
00119 print subroutines used to print the questions and the answers. Other printing
00120 methods can be used instead of the standard ones. An example of how to do this
00121 is demonstrated with pop_up_list_print_q() below.
00122 
00123 =cut
00124 
00125 # ^function new_match_list
00126 # ^uses Match::new
00127 # ^uses &std_print_q
00128 # ^uses &std_print_a
00129 
00130 sub new_match_list {
00131     new Match(random(1,2000,1), \&std_print_q, \&std_print_a);
00132 }
00133 
00134 =back
00135 
00136 =cut
00137 
00138 ################################################################################
00139 
00140 =head2 Select lists
00141 
00142 =over
00143 
00144 =item new_select_list
00145 
00146  $sl = new_select_list();
00147 
00148 new_select_list() creates a new Select object and initializes it with sensible
00149 defaults. It is equivalent to:
00150 
00151  $sl = new Select(random(1,2000,1), ~~&std_print_q, ~~&std_print_a);
00152 
00153 The parameters to the Select constructor are the same as those for the Match
00154 constrcutor described above under new_match_list().
00155 
00156 See the documentation for the Select class to see how to use this object to
00157 create a true/false question.
00158 
00159 std_print_a is only intended to be used for debugging with select lists, as
00160 there is rarely a reason to print out the answers to a select list.
00161 
00162 =cut
00163 
00164 # ^function new_select_list
00165 # ^uses Select::new
00166 # ^uses &std_print_q
00167 # ^uses &std_print_a
00168 
00169 sub new_select_list {
00170     new Select(random(1,2000,1), \&std_print_q, \&std_print_a);
00171 }
00172 
00173 =item new_pop_up_select_list()
00174 
00175  $sl = new_pop_up_select_list();
00176 
00177 new_popup_select_list() creates a new Select object and initializes it such that
00178 it will render as a popup list. It is equivalent to:
00179 
00180  $selectlist = new Select(random(1,2000,1), ~~&pop_up_list_print_q, ~~&std_print_a);
00181 
00182 =cut
00183 
00184 # ^function new_pop_up_select_list
00185 # ^uses Select::new
00186 # ^uses &pop_up_list_print_q
00187 # ^uses &std_print_a
00188 
00189 sub new_pop_up_select_list {
00190     new Select(random(1,2000,1), \&pop_up_list_print_q, \&std_print_a);
00191 }
00192 
00193 =back
00194 
00195 =cut
00196 
00197 ################################################################################
00198 
00199 =head2 Multiple choice quesitons
00200 
00201 =over
00202 
00203 =item new_multiple_choice()
00204 
00205  $mc = new_multiple_choice();
00206 
00207 new_multiple_choice() creates a new Multiple object that presents a question and
00208 a number possible answers, only one of which can be chosen. It is equivalent to:
00209 
00210  $mc = new Multiple(random(1,2000,1), ~~&std_print_q, ~~&radio_print_a);
00211 
00212 The parameters to the Multiple constructor are the same as those for the Match
00213 constrcutor described above under new_match_list().
00214 
00215 =cut
00216 
00217 # ^function new_multiple_choice
00218 # ^uses Multiple::new
00219 # ^uses &std_print_q
00220 # ^uses &radio_print_a
00221 
00222 sub new_multiple_choice {
00223     new Multiple(random(1,2000,1), \&std_print_q, \&radio_print_a);
00224 }
00225 
00226 =item new_checkbox_multiple_choice()
00227 
00228  $mc = new_checkbox_multiple_choice();
00229 
00230 new_checkbox_multiple_choice() creates a new Multiple object that presents a
00231 question and a number possible answers, any number of which can be chosen. It is
00232 equivalent to:
00233 
00234  $mc = new Multiple(random(1,2000,1), ~~&std_print_q, ~~&checkbox_print_a);
00235 
00236 =cut
00237 
00238 # ^function new_checkbox_multiple_choice
00239 # ^uses Multiple::new
00240 # ^uses &std_print_q
00241 # ^uses &checkbox_print_a
00242 sub new_checkbox_multiple_choice {
00243     new Multiple(random(1,2000,1), \&std_print_q, \&checkbox_print_a);
00244 }
00245 
00246 =back
00247 
00248 =cut

00250 ################################################################################
00251 
00252 =head2 Question printing subroutines
00253 
00254 =over
00255 
00256 =item std_print_q()
00257 
00258  # $list can be a matching list, a select list, or a multiple choice list
00259  $list->rf_print_q(~~&std_print_q);
00260  TEXT($list->print_q);
00261 
00262 This formatting routine is the default method for formatting the way questions
00263 are printed for each of the three List sub-classes. It lists the questions
00264 vertically, numbering them sequentially and providing an answer blank before
00265 each question. std_print_q() checks which mode the user is trying to print the
00266 questions from and returns the appropriately formatted string.
00267 
00268 =cut
00269 
00270 
00271 # ^function std_print_q
00272 
00273 sub std_print_q {
00274     my $self = shift;
00275     my (@questions) = @_;
00276     my $length = $self->{ans_rule_len};
00277     my $out = "";
00278     #if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML' || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth') {
00279     if ($main::displayMode =~ /^HTML/) {
00280             my $i=1; my $quest; $out = "\n<P>\n";
00281         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00282              $out.= ans_rule($length) . "&nbsp;<B>$i.</B> $quest<BR>";
00283              $i++;
00284         }
00285     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00286             my $i=1; my $quest; $out = "\\par\n";
00287         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00288              $out.= ans_rule($length) . "\\begin{rawhtml}<B>$i. </B>\\end{rawhtml} $quest\\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml}\n";
00289              $i++;
00290         }
00291     }  elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00292         $out = "\n\\par\\begin{enumerate}\n";
00293         my $i=1; my $quest;
00294         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00295             $out .= "\\item[" . ans_rule($length) . "$i.] $quest\n";
00296             $i++;
00297         }
00298         $out .= "\\end{enumerate}\n";
00299     } else {
00300         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: std_print_q: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00301     }
00302     $out;
00303 
00304 }
00305 
00306 =item pop_up_list_print_q()
00307 
00308  $sl->rf_print_q(~~&pop_up_list_print_q);
00309  $sl->ra_pop_up_list([T => 'True', F => 'False']);
00310  TEXT($sl->print_q);
00311 
00312 Alternate method for print questions with pop up lists.
00313 
00314 This printing routine is used to print the questions for a true/false or other
00315 select list with a preceding pop up list of possible answers. A list of values
00316 and labels need to be given to the pop_up_list so that the intended answer is
00317 returned when a student selects an answer form the list. Note the use of => in
00318 the example above to associate the values on the left with the labels on the
00319 right, this means that, for instance, the student will see the word True in the
00320 pop_up_list but the answer that is returned to the grader is T, so that it
00321 corresponds with what the professor typed in as the answer when using
00322 $sl->qa('blah blah', 'T');
00323 
00324 =cut
00325 
00326 
00327 # ^function pop_up_list_print_q
00328 
00329 sub pop_up_list_print_q {
00330     my $self = shift;
00331     my (@questions) = @_;
00332     my $length = $self->{ans_rule_len};
00333     my @list = @{$self->{ra_pop_up_list} };
00334     my $out = "";
00335 
00336     #if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML' || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth') {
00337     if ($main::displayMode =~ /^HTML/) {
00338         my $i=1; my $quest;
00339         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00340              $out.= "\n<p>" . pop_up_list(@list) . "&nbsp;<B>$i.</B> $quest";
00341              $i++;
00342         }
00343         $out .= "<br>\n";
00344     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00345         my $i=1; my $quest;
00346         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00347              $out.= " \\begin{rawhtml}<p><B>\\end{rawhtml}" . pop_up_list(@list) . " $i. \\begin{rawhtml}</B>\\end{rawhtml}   $quest";
00348              $i++;
00349         }
00350         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00351     }  elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00352         $out = "\n\\par\\begin{enumerate}\n";
00353         my $i=1; my $quest;
00354         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00355             $out .= "\\item[" .  pop_up_list(@list) . "$i.] $quest\n";
00356             $i++;
00357         }
00358         $out .= "\\end{enumerate}\n";
00359     } else {
00360         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: pop_up_list_print_q: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00361     }
00362     $out;
00363 
00364 }
00365 
00366 
00367 
00368 =item quest_first_pop_up_list_print_q()
00369 
00370  $sl->rf_print_q(~~&quest_first_pop_up_list_print_q);
00371  $sl->ra_pop_up_list([T => 'True', F => 'False']);
00372  TEXT($sl->print_q);
00373 
00374 Similar to pop_up_list_print_q(), but places the popup list after the question
00375 text in the output.
00376 
00377 =cut
00378 
00379 # To put pop-up-list at the end of a question.
00380 # contributed by Mark Schmitt 3-6-03
00381 
00382 # ^function quest_first_pop_up_list_print_q
00383 
00384 sub quest_first_pop_up_list_print_q {
00385     my $self = shift;
00386     my (@questions) = @_;
00387     my $length = $self->{ans_rule_len};
00388     my @list = @{$self->{ra_pop_up_list} };
00389     my $out = "";
00390 
00391     if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML_MathJax'
00392      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_dpng'
00393      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML'
00394      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth'
00395      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_jsMath'
00396      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_asciimath' 
00397      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_LaTeXMathML'
00398      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_img') {
00399         my $i=1; my $quest;
00400         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00401              $out.= "\n<p>" .  "&nbsp; $quest" . pop_up_list(@list);
00402              $i++;
00403         }
00404         $out .= "<br>\n";
00405     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00406         my $i=1; my $quest;
00407         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00408              $out.= " \\begin{rawhtml}<p><B>\\end{rawhtml}" . pop_up_list(@list) . " $i. \\begin{rawhtml}</B>\\end{rawhtml}   $quest";
00409              $i++;
00410         }
00411         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00412     }  elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00413         $out = "\n\\par\\begin{enumerate}\n";
00414         my $i=1; my $quest;
00415         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00416             $out .= "\\item[" .  pop_up_list(@list) . "$i.] $quest\n";
00417             $i++;
00418         }
00419         $out .= "\\end{enumerate}\n";
00420     } else {
00421         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: pop_up_list_print_q: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00422     }
00423     $out;
00424 
00425 }
00426 
00427 =item ans_in_middle_pop_up_list_print_q()
00428 
00429  $sl->rf_print_q(~~&ans_in_middle_pop_up_list_print_q);
00430  $sl->ra_pop_up_list([T => 'True', F => 'False']);
00431  TEXT($sl->print_q);
00432 
00433 Similar to quest_first_pop_up_list_print_q(), except that no linebreaks are
00434 printed between questions, allowing for the popup list to be placed in the
00435 middle of the text of a problem.
00436 
00437 =cut
00438 
00439 # To put pop-up-list in the middle of a question.
00440 # contributed by Mark Schmitt 3-6-03
00441 
00442 # ^function ans_in_middle_pop_up_list_print_q
00443 
00444 sub ans_in_middle_pop_up_list_print_q {
00445     my $self = shift;
00446     my (@questions) = @_;
00447     my $length = $self->{ans_rule_len};
00448     my @list = @{$self->{ra_pop_up_list} };
00449     my $out = "";
00450 
00451     if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML_MathJax'
00452      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_dpng'
00453      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML'
00454      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth'
00455      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_jsMath'
00456      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_asciimath' 
00457      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_LaTeXMathML'
00458      || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_img') {
00459         my $i=1; my $quest;
00460         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00461              $out.= "" .  "&nbsp; $quest" . pop_up_list(@list);
00462              $i++;
00463         }
00464         $out .= "";
00465     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00466         my $i=1; my $quest;
00467         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00468              $out.= " \\begin{rawhtml}<p><B>\\end{rawhtml}" . pop_up_list(@list) . " $i. \\begin{rawhtml}</B>\\end{rawhtml}   $quest";
00469              $i++;
00470         }
00471         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00472     }  elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00473         $out = "\n\\par\\begin{enumerate}\n";
00474         my $i=1; my $quest;
00475         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00476             $out .= "\\item[" .  pop_up_list(@list) . "$i.] $quest\n";
00477             $i++;
00478         }
00479         $out .= "\\end{enumerate}\n";
00480     } else {
00481         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: pop_up_list_print_q: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00482     }
00483     $out;
00484 
00485 }

00487 =item units_list_print_q
00488 
00489 A simple popup question printer. No question text is printed, instead the
00490 pop_up_list contents only are printed as a popup menu.

00494 # Units for physics class

00497 # ^function units_list_print_q
00498 
00499 sub units_list_print_q {
00500     my $self = shift;
00501     my (@questions) = @_;
00502     my $length = $self->{ans_rule_len};
00503     my @list = @{$self->{ra_pop_up_list} };
00504     my $out = '';
00505 
00506     $out.= pop_up_list(@list);
00507 
00508     $out;
00509 }

00515 ################################################################################
00516 
00517 =head2 Answer printing subroutines
00518 
00519 =over
00520 
00521 =item std_print_a
00522 
00523  # $list can be a matching list, a select list, or a multiple choice list
00524  $list->rf_print_a(~~&std_print_a);
00525  TEXT($list->print_a);
00526 
00527 This simple formatting routine is the default method for formatting the answers
00528 for matching lists.  It lists the answers vertically lettered sequentially.
00529 
00530 =cut
00531 
00532 #Standard method of printing answers in a matching list
00533 # ^function std_print_a
00534 sub std_print_a {
00535     my $self = shift;
00536     my(@array) = @_;
00537     my $i = 0;
00538     my @alpha = ('A'..'Z', 'AA'..'ZZ');
00539     my $letter;
00540     my  $out=   &main::M3(
00541                     "\\begin{enumerate}\n",
00542                     " \\begin{rawhtml} <OL TYPE=\"A\" VALUE=\"1\"> \\end{rawhtml} ",
00543                     # kludge to fix IE/CSS problem
00544                     #"<OL COMPACT TYPE=\"A\" START=\"1\">\n"
00545                     "<BLOCKQUOTE>\n"
00546     ) ;
00547     my $elem;
00548     foreach $elem (@array) {
00549         $letter = shift @alpha;
00550         $out .= &main::M3(
00551                     "\\item[$main::ALPHABET[$i].] $elem\n",
00552                     " \\begin{rawhtml} <LI> \\end{rawhtml} $elem  ",
00553                     #"<LI> $elem</LI>\n"
00554                     "<br /> <b>$letter.</b> $elem\n"
00555         ) ;
00556         $i++;
00557     }
00558     $out .= &main::M3(
00559                 "\\end{enumerate}\n",
00560                 " \\begin{rawhtml} </OL>\n \\end{rawhtml} ",
00561                 #"</OL>\n"
00562                 "</BLOCKQUOTE>\n"
00563     ) ;
00564     $out;
00565 
00566 }
00567 
00568 =item radio_print_a()
00569 
00570  # $list can be a matching list, a select list, or a multiple choice list
00571  $list->rf_print_q(~~&radio_print_q);
00572  TEXT($list->print_q);
00573 
00574 This simple printing routine is used to print the answers to multiple choice
00575 questions in a bulleted style with radio buttons preceding each possible answer.
00576 When a multiple choice object is created, a reference to radio_print_a is passed
00577 to that object so that it can be used from within the object later.
00578 
00579 radio_print_a checks which mode the user is trying to print the answers from and
00580 returns the appropriately formatted string.
00581 
00582 =cut
00583 
00584 #Alternate method of printing answers as a list of radio buttons for multiple choice
00585 #Method for naming radio buttons is no longer round about and hackish
00586 
00587 # ^function radio_print_a
00588 sub radio_print_a {
00589     my $self = shift;
00590     my (@answers) = @_;
00591     my $out = "";
00592     my $i =0;
00593     my @in = ();
00594     #if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML' || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth') {
00595     if ($main::displayMode =~ /^HTML/) {
00596         foreach my $ans (@answers) {
00597             push (@in, ($main::ALPHABET[$i], "<B> $main::ALPHABET[$i]. </B> $ans"));
00598             $i++;
00599         }
00600         my @radio_buttons = ans_radio_buttons(@in);
00601         $out = "\n<BR>" . join "\n<BR>", @radio_buttons;
00602         $out .= "<BR>\n";
00603     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00604         foreach my $ans (@answers) {
00605             push (@in, ($main::ALPHABET[$i], "\\begin{rawhtml}<B> $main::ALPHABET[$i]. </B> \\end{rawhtml} $ans"));
00606             $i++;
00607         }
00608         my @radio_buttons = ans_radio_buttons(@in);
00609         $out = "\\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml}" . join "\\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml}", @radio_buttons;
00610         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00611     }  elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00612         foreach my $ans (@answers) {
00613             push (@in, ($main::ALPHABET[$i], "$main::ALPHABET[$i]. $ans"));
00614             $i++;
00615         }
00616         my @radio_buttons = ans_radio_buttons(@in);
00617         #$out = "\n\\par\\begin{itemize}\n";
00618         $out .= join '', @radio_buttons;
00619         #$out .= "\\end{itemize}\n";
00620     } else {
00621         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: radio_print_a: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00622     }
00623     $out;
00624 
00625 }
00626 
00627 =item checkbox_print_a()
00628 
00629  # $list can be a matching list, a select list, or a multiple choice list
00630  $list->rf_print_q(~~&radio_print_q);
00631  TEXT($list->print_q);
00632 
00633 This simple printing routine is used to print the answers to multiple choice
00634 questions in a bulleted style with checkboxes preceding each possible answer.
00635 When a multiple choice object is created, a reference to checkbox_print_a is passed
00636 to that object so that it can be used from within the object later.
00637 
00638 checkbox_print_a checks which mode the user is trying to print the answers from and
00639 returns the appropriately formatted string.
00640 
00641 =cut
00642 
00643 
00644 
00645 # ^function checkbox_print_a
00646 sub checkbox_print_a {
00647     my $self = shift;
00648     my (@answers) = @_;
00649     my $out = "";
00650     my $i =0;
00651     my @in = ();
00652 #   if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML' || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth') {
00653     if ($main::displayMode =~ /^HTML/) {
00654         foreach my $ans (@answers) {
00655             push (@in, ($main::ALPHABET[$i], "<B> $main::ALPHABET[$i]. </B> $ans"));
00656             $i++;
00657         }
00658         my @checkboxes = ans_checkbox(@in);
00659         $out = "\n<BR>" . join "\n<BR>", @checkboxes;
00660         $out .= "<BR>\n";
00661     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00662         foreach my $ans (@answers) {
00663             push (@in, ($main::ALPHABET[$i], "\\begin{rawhtml}<B> $main::ALPHABET[$i]. </B> \\end{rawhtml} $ans"));
00664             $i++;
00665         }
00666         my @checkboxes = ans_checkbox(@in);
00667         $out = "\\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml}" . join "\\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml}", @checkboxes;
00668         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00669     }  elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00670         foreach my $ans (@answers) {
00671             push (@in, ($main::ALPHABET[$i], "$main::ALPHABET[$i]. $ans"));
00672             $i++;
00673         }
00674         my @radio_buttons = ans_checkbox(@in);
00675         #$out = "\n\\par\\begin{itemize}\n";
00676         $out .= join '', @radio_buttons ;
00677         #$out .= "\\end{itemize}\n";
00678     } else {
00679         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: checkbox_print_a: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00680     }
00681     $out;
00682 
00683 }
00684 
00685 =back
00686 
00687 =cut
00688 
00689 ################################################################################
00690 
00691 =head2 Legacy macros
00692 
00693 These are maintained for backward compatibility. They can still be useful in
00694 constructing non-standard lists that don't fit the various list objects. In
00695 general the using the list objects is likely to give better results and is
00696 preferred.
00697 
00698 =over
00699 
00700 =item [DEPRECATED] qa()
00701 
00702  qa($questions, $answers, @new_qa);
00703 
00704 $questions and $answers are references to arrays, and @new_qa is a list of
00705 questions and answers to add to the $questions and $answers arrays.
00706 
00707 =cut
00708 
00709 # ^function qa   [DEPRECATED]
00710 # 
00711 sub qa {
00712     my($questionsRef,$answersRef,@questANDanswer) = @_;
00713     while (@questANDanswer) {
00714         push(@$questionsRef,shift(@questANDanswer));
00715         push(@$answersRef,shift(@questANDanswer));
00716 
00717     }
00718 }
00719 
00720 =item [DEPRECATED] invert()
00721 
00722  @b = invert(@a);
00723 
00724 Inverts an arrays values and indexes. For example, C<invert(1,2,4,8)> returns
00725 C<undef,0,1,undef,2,undef,undef,undef,4>.
00726 
00727 =cut
00728 
00729 # ^function invert   [DEPRECATED]
00730 sub invert {
00731     my @array = @_;
00732     my @out = ();
00733     my $i;
00734     for ($i=0;$i<=$#array;$i++) {
00735         $out[$array[$i]]=$i;
00736     }
00737     @out;
00738 }
00739 
00740 =item [DEPRECATED] NchooseK()
00741 
00742  @b = NchooseK($N, $K);
00743 
00744 Selects $K random nonrepeating elements in the range 0 to $N-1.
00745 
00746 =cut
00747 
00748 # ^function NchooseK   [DEPRECATED]
00749 
00750 sub NchooseK {
00751     my($n,$k)=@_;;
00752     my @array = 0..($n-1);
00753     my @out = ();
00754     while (@out<$k) {
00755         push(@out, splice(@array,    random(0,$#array,1) ,         1) );
00756     }
00757     @out;
00758 }
00759 
00760 =item [DEPRECATED] shuffle()
00761 
00762  @b = shuffle($i);
00763 
00764 Returns the integers from 0 to $i-1 in random order.
00765 
00766 =cut
00767 
00768 # ^function shuffle   [DEPRECATED]
00769 
00770 sub shuffle {
00771     my ($i) = @_;
00772     my @out = &NchooseK($i,$i);
00773     @out;
00774 }
00775 
00776 =item [DEPRECATED] match_questions_list()
00777 
00778 =cut
00779 
00780 # ^function match_questions_list   [DEPRECATED]
00781 
00782 sub match_questions_list {
00783     my (@questions) = @_;
00784     my $out = "";
00785     #if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML' || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth') {
00786     if ($main::displayMode =~ /^HTML/) {
00787         my $i=1; my $quest;
00788         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00789              $out.= "\n<BR>" . ans_rule(4) . "<B>$i.</B> $quest";
00790              $i++;
00791         }
00792         $out .= "<br>\n";
00793     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00794         my $i=1; my $quest;
00795         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00796              $out.= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} " . ans_rule(4) . "\\begin{rawhtml}<B>\\end{rawhtml} $i. \\begin{rawhtml}</B>\\end{rawhtml}   $quest"; #"$i.   $quest";
00797              $i++;
00798         }
00799         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00800     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00801         $out = "\n\\par\\begin{enumerate}\n";
00802         my $i=1; my $quest;
00803         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00804             $out .= "\\item[" . ans_rule(3) . "$i.] $quest\n";
00805             $i++;
00806             }
00807         $out .= "\\end{enumerate}\n";
00808     } else {
00809         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: match_questions_list: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00810     }
00811     $out;
00812 }
00813 
00814 =item [DEPRECATED] match_questions_list_varbox()
00815 
00816 =cut
00817 
00818 # ^function match_questions_list_varbox   [DEPRECATED]
00819 
00820 sub match_questions_list_varbox {
00821     my ($length, @questions) = @_;
00822     my $out = "";
00823     #if ($main::displayMode eq 'HTML' || $main::displayMode eq 'HTML_tth') {
00824     if ($main::displayMode =~ /^HTML/) {
00825         my $i=1; my $quest;
00826         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00827             $out.=  "\n<BR>" . ans_rule($length) . "<B>$i.</B> $quest";
00828             $i++;
00829         }
00830         $out .= "<br>\n";
00831     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'Latex2HTML') {
00832         my $i=1; my $quest;
00833         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00834             $out.=  " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} " . ans_rule($length) . "\\begin{rawhtml}<B>\\end{rawhtml} $i. \\begin{rawhtml}</B>\\end{rawhtml}   $quest"; #"$i.   $quest";
00835             $i++;
00836         }
00837         $out .= " \\begin{rawhtml}<BR>\\end{rawhtml} ";
00838     } elsif ($main::displayMode eq 'TeX') {
00839         $out = "\n\\par\\begin{enumerate}\n";
00840         my $i=1; my $quest;
00841         foreach $quest (@questions) {
00842             $out .= "\\item[" . ans_rule($length) . "$i.] $quest\n";
00843             $i++;
00844         }
00845         $out .= "\\end{enumerate}\n";
00846     } else {
00847         $out = "Error: PGchoicemacros: match_questions_list_varbox: Unknown displayMode: $main::displayMode.\n";
00848     }
00849     $out;
00850 }
00851
